explanation: the preamble (for exporting)
entity 0 claiming that 1 is true; any kind of quotation basically
0 is the reason why 1 is true; note that 0 and 1 could be formulas talking about the past stating that something was the reason why something was the case at some point in time
0 would cause 1 to be true; this also covers speculations about how things could have been if past events would have gone differently
entity 0 makes a normative statement that 1 should be made true without specifying who should make 1 true
0 should be made true; note that it is unspecified who should see to make 0 true; this 'should' is distinct from specifying uncertainty
it is possible that 0 is true; in the sense that nothing prevents 0 from being true
1 would be bad for entity 0
1 is bad for entity 0
1 would be good for entity 0
1 is good for entity 0
entity 0 believes 1 is true
entity 0 has the ability to perform action 1
0 usually implies 1; in the sense that it might not always be the case but one can assume it is unless evidence for the contrary is presented
in situation/point in time 0 1 was/is/would be the case; e.g. 'in the industrial revolution {1}'; so named points in time together with something that was or will be the case there
situations 0 and 1 are similar
concepts (people or situations) 0 and 1 are similar; e.g. Hitler comparisons or comparing the brexit referendum to some other vote
entity 1 prefers 2 to be true over 0; e.g. utterances like 'xy would rather have 0 than 2'
entity 0 is accused of being biased
entity 0 is accused of being somehow unqualified to make meaningful contributions to the dialogue; e.g. 'idiot'
entity 0 should make 1 true
entity 0 is accused of lying about truth of 1; 0's beliefs about 1 don't reflect what 0 said about 1
entity 0 is morally bad and should be condemned; ad-hominem-catchall
truth of 0 is necessary for 1 to be true
if 0 then 1; note that if truth of 0 is said to be responsible/cause truth of 1 then it would rather be pattern 1
entity 0 is claimed to be part of entity 1 (most likely some group)
all entities in entity 0 have property 1 e.g. brexit supporters are idiots
entity 2 is claimed to be part of group/entity 0 whose members generally know truth of 1; e.g. as a scientist I know that this is true
falsity of formula 0 is claimed
entity 0 is claimed to be honest w.r.t. formula 1 in the sense that they say what they believe
by executing action 0 truth of 1 would be eventually achieved
entity 0 executed action 1

template: [\{?0 : entity \text{ or list of } entities\};\{{?1 : action \text{ or list of } actions \text{ or list of lists of }actions}\} : {?2 : entity \text{ or list of }entities}]({?3 : formula})
explanation: the entities 0 can collaborate to enforce truth of 3 as long as entities 2 execute one of the (joint) actions from 1
most entities in entity 0 have property 1 e.g. most brexit supporters are idiots
entity 0 claims that 1 might cause 2 to be true
entity 0 knows that 1 is true (this implies that 1 actually is true!)
formula 0 is necessarily true in the sense that it cannot be the case that 0 is false
formula 0 is permitted in the sense that it is morally acceptable to make 0 true or that 0 is true
entity 0 states that entities in group 1 should make 2 true

template: L_{{?0 : entity}} ({?1 : formula});({?1} \cfac L_{{?2 : entity}} bad)
explanation: entity 0 warns of 1 being bad
some entities in 0 have property 1
nobody in 0 has property 1
